questions.text: Which of the following hormones will stimulate lobular development of the breast?
questions.solution:
Progesterone stimulates lobular development of the breast and differentiation of the epithelium. 

Hormone Action
Estrogen Ductal development
Progesterone Lobular development and differentiation of the epithelium
Prolactin Lactogenesis
Oxytocin Milk ejection

questions.text: Which of the following is not true regarding lymphatic drainage of the breast?

choices.text: The axillary nodes receive approximately 85% of the drainage.
The lateral group is located along the axillary vein.
The anterior group drains most of the breast.
Lymph nodes are divided on the basis of their relation to the pectoralis major.

questions.solution: Lymph nodes are divided on the basis of their relation to the pectoralis minor, not the pectoralis major.

questions.text: A 55-year-old woman presented to the OPD with a 4 x 2 cm painless lump in the left breast. She is planned for a mastectomy. Sentinel lymph node biopsy done showed involvement of level 1 lymph nodes. Which of the following lymph nodes will not be affected in her case?
questions.solution: Interpectoral lymph nodes are level 2 axillary lymph nodes. Level 1 axillary lymph nodes include anterior, lateral, and posterior/subscapular nodes.

questions.text: During a routine antenatal checkup, a pregnant woman in her third trimester is noticed to have accessory nipples. Which of the following does this condition refer to?
questions.solution:
Polythelia or supernumerary nipples refer to the presence of accessory nipples. 

Polymastia or polymazia is a congenital anomaly with the presence of accessory breast tissue.

Symmastia is a condition characterized by webbing between the breasts, at the midline.

Supernumerary mazia is the presence of accessory breasts with a complete ductal system, areola, and nipple in addition to two normal breasts.

Note: Athelia refers to the absence of nipples, and amastia refers to the congenital absence of the breast and nipple.

The image below shows a third nipple below the left breast:

questions.text: Which of the following is not true regarding accessory breast tissue?

choices.text: It is associated with Poland’s syndrome
It develops along the line of Schultz
It is also known as polymazia

questions.solution:
Poland’s syndrome is not associated with accessory breast tissue. It is associated with amastia with the absence of the sternal portion of the pectoralis major muscle.

Polymastia or polymazia is a congenital anomaly in which there is presence of accessory breast tissue. Axilla is the most frequent site for accessory breast tissue along the line of Schultz. Accessory breast tissue develops along the milk line/ line of Schultz, which appears by the 6th week of embryonic development. The milk line extends from the axilla to the inguinal region. It is ectodermal in origin.

The image below shows the milk line/ line of Schultz:

The image below shows accessory breast tissue in the right axilla:

questions.text: All of the following statements about amazia are true except _____.

choices.text: Amazia may be associated with Poland's syndrome
Amazia is the absence of the nipple.
Amazia is often the result of surgical intervention.
Amazia may be caused by radiation therapy.

questions.solution:
Amazia is a condition wherein the breast tissue is absent, but the nipple-areolar complex is present. It results from iatrogenic causes such as radiation, excision of a misdiagnosed infantile or childhood mass that actually represented breast buds or incision and drainage of a suspected abscess.

Note: Amastia is the congenital absence of the breast and nipple. Athelia is the absence of the nipple.

questions.text: Which of the following will you not see in a patient with Poland’s syndrome?

choices.text: Athelia with the absence of the pectoralis major
Amastia with the absence of pectoralis major

questions.solution:
Athelia with absence of pectoralis major is not associated with Poland’s syndrome.

Poland’s syndrome is associated with unilateral:

  • Amastia with the absence of the sternal portion of the pectoralis major muscle
  • Abnormalities of the chest wall muscles
  • Loss of costal cartilage
  • Digital abnormalities such as brachysyndactyly, which is the abnormal shortness of the fingers or toes combined with webbing between the adjacent digits

In some cases, associated skeletal abnormalities, such as underdeveloped or absent upper ribs, underdeveloped forearm bones, and elevation of the shoulder blade (Sprengel deformity) may also be present.

Note: Poland's syndrome is a constellation of anomalies with varying clinical presentations. Patients with this syndrome can present with amazia (absence of one or both of the mammary glands) or amastia (complete absence of breast tissue, nipple, and areola) in addition to any or all of the above-mentioned abnormalities.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman presents to the clinic with pain over the lateral aspect of her right breast for the past 5 days. Examination finding is as shown in the image. Which of the following is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of Mondor's disease. The image shows the presence of a subcutaneous cord and a narrow shallow groove along the side of the cord.

Mondor’s disease is the thrombophlebitis of the superficial veins of the breast and anterior chest wall. The most commonly involved vein is the lateral thoracic vein. Patients usually present with pain along the lateral chest wall and a tender, firm cord below the breast. It is a benign condition and gets resolved on its own within 4-6 weeks. Warm compresses and anti-inflammatory medicines can be used to reduce pain. If the symptoms persist despite medications, the affected segment of the vein can be excised.

Option A: Tietze’s syndrome is a benign inflammation of one or more costal cartilages.

Option B: Zuska disease is the subcutaneous abscess of the breast tissue beneath the areola of the nipple. It is also called a subareolar abscess.

Option D: Stewart–Treves Syndrome is characterized by lymphangiosarcoma in chronic long-standing lymphedema following mastectomy.

questions.text: Which of the following is the commonest cause of pathological nipple discharge in a non-lactating woman?
questions.solution:
The most common cause of nipple discharge in a non-lactating woman is duct ectasia. The discharge is usually black or greenish in color.

Option B: Intraductal papilloma is the most common cause of bloody nipple discharge. It is a true polyp of the epithelium-lined ducts of the breast. Contrary to what one might expect, they are not associated with an increased risk of breast cancer.

Option C: Paget's disease of the breast can present with discharge from the surface of the nipple.

Option D: Galactorrhea is the milk production from breasts unrelated to pregnancy or lactation.

Related Pearl: Discharge from the Nipple

From the surface:

  • Paget’s disease
  • Skin diseases (eczema, psoriasis)
  • Rare causes (e.g., chancre)

From a single duct:

  • Blood-stained:
    • Intraductal papilloma (M/C cause)
    • Intraductal carcinoma
    • Duct ectasia
  • Serous (any colour):
    • Fibrocystic disease
    • Duct ectasia
    • Carcinoma

From multiple ducts:

  • Blood-stained:
    • Carcinoma (M/C cause)
    • Ectasia
    • Fibrocystic disease
  • Black or green:
    • Duct ectasia
  • Purulent:
    • Infection
  • Serous:
    • Fibrocystic disease (M/C cause)
    • Duct ectasia
    • Carcinoma
  • Milk:
    • Lactation
    • Rare causes (hypothyroidism, pituitary tumour)

questions.text: A chronic smoker presented with complaints of intermittent discharge from bilateral nipples for the past few months. On compression of her breast during the examination, a discharge was observed as shown below. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis of a patient with greenish discharge from multiple ducts is duct ectasia.

Duct ectasia is the dilatation of breast ducts. It is the most common cause of nipple discharge in non-lactating women. This condition is associated with smoking and diabetes. The initial stage of this disease consists of dilatation of one or more lactiferous ducts. These ducts get filled with stagnant brown or green-colored secretions. In the later stages, the accumulation of fluid in the lactiferous ducts leads to infection and inflammation, causing periductal mastitis. Patients may present with nipple discharge, abscess, fistula, or nipple retraction.

Treatment includes:

  • Initial stages - oral antibiotics, needle aspiration, or incision and drainage of the abscess
  • Recurrent episodes - Hadfield operation (cone excision of multiple ducts)
  • A single duct involvement - microdochectomy.

Related Pearl: Discharge from the Nipple

From the surface:

  • Paget’s disease
  • Skin diseases (eczema, psoriasis)
  • Rare causes (e.g., chancre)

From a single duct:

  • Blood-stained:
    • Intraductal papilloma (M/C cause)
    • Intraductal carcinoma
    • Duct ectasia
  • Serous (any colour):
    • Fibrocystic disease
    • Duct ectasia
    • Carcinoma

From multiple ducts:

  • Blood-stained:
    • Carcinoma (M/C cause)
    • Ectasia
    • Fibrocystic disease
  • Black or green:
    • Duct ectasia
  • Purulent:
    • Infection
  • Serous:
    • Fibrocystic disease (M/C cause)
    • Duct ectasia
    • Carcinoma
  • Milk:
    • Lactation
    • Rare causes (hypothyroidism, pituitary tumour)

questions.text: What is the best method of management in a patient with recurrent episodes of multiple duct ectasia?

choices.text: Wide excision involving the affected ducts

questions.solution:
The best method of management in a patient with multiple duct ectasia is to perform Hadfield's operation. This operation consists of the excision of all the major lactiferous ducts.

The initial stages of duct ectasia can be managed by oral antibiotics, needle aspiration, or incision and drainage of the abscess. Recurrent episodes of infection are best managed by Hadfield operation. If a single duct is involved, then microdochectomy is performed.

questions.text: Amongst the following, the most common cause of blood-stained nipple discharge from a single duct is:
questions.solution:
Ductal papilloma is the most common cause of blood-stained nipple discharge from a single duct.

Solitary intraductal papillomas are true polyps of the ducts which are usually small (<1 cm) but may grow to 4-5 cm. They are often associated with bloody nipple discharge. They do not have malignant potential. Treatment is by excision.

Note: The most common cause of blood-stained discharge from multiple ducts is carcinoma.  

Related Pearl: Discharge from the Nipple

From the surface:

  • Paget’s disease
  • Skin diseases (eczema, psoriasis)
  • Rare causes (e.g., chancre)

From a single duct:

  • Blood-stained:
    • Intraductal papilloma (M/C cause)
    • Intraductal carcinoma
    • Duct ectasia
  • Serous (any colour):
    • Fibrocystic disease
    • Duct ectasia
    • Carcinoma

From multiple ducts:

  • Blood-stained:
    • Carcinoma (M/C cause)
    • Ectasia
    • Fibrocystic disease
  • Black or green:
    • Duct ectasia
  • Purulent:
    • Infection
  • Serous:
    • Fibrocystic disease (M/C cause)
    • Duct ectasia
    • Carcinoma
  • Milk:
    • Lactation
    • Rare causes (hypothyroidism, pituitary tumour)

questions.text: A probe is inserted into the duct from which the nipple discharge is emerging. A tennis racquet incision is made and the flap is dissected to reach the duct. The duct is then excised.  This  procedure is known as?

choices.text: Wide excision of the lactiferous duct.

questions.solution:
Microdochectomy is the excision of the entire lactiferous duct (single duct disease). It is done for duct papilloma.

Microdochectomy:

  • In a duct papilloma where no palpable mass is present, the duct is expressed to observe the discharge.
  • A fine probe or stiff nylon suture is gently inserted into the duct, and the probe is secured to the nipple skin using silk sutures to prevent displacement during the procedure.
  • A tennis racquet shaped incision is made to elevate the skin flaps, and the duct with the probe is excised along with the skin flap for 5 cm until the papilloma is identified (The papilloma will always be located within 5 cm from the duct orifice).
  • The wound is closed without a drain, and a compression bandage is applied.

It is ideal to rule out DCIS by frozen section biopsy.

Cone excision and wide excision are done under major duct excision (Adair-Haldfield operation). It is done for duct ectasias with multiple duct involvement and multiple papillomas.

Related Pearl: Discharge from the Nipple

From the surface:

  • Paget’s disease
  • Skin diseases (eczema, psoriasis)
  • Rare causes (e.g., chancre)

From a single duct:

  • Blood-stained:
    • Intraductal papilloma (M/C cause)
    • Intraductal carcinoma
    • Duct ectasia
  • Serous (any colour):
    • Fibrocystic disease
    • Duct ectasia
    • Carcinoma

From multiple ducts:

  • Blood-stained:
    • Carcinoma (M/C cause)
    • Ectasia
    • Fibrocystic disease
  • Black or green:
    • Duct ectasia
  • Purulent:
    • Infection
  • Serous:
    • Fibrocystic disease (M/C cause)
    • Duct ectasia
    • Carcinoma
  • Milk:
    • Lactation
    • Rare causes (hypothyroidism, pituitary tumour)

questions.text: Which of the following aberration of normal development and involution of breast tissue is present in patients with fibroadenoma?
questions.solution:
In fibroadenoma, aberration of normal lobular development is present. 

It arises from hyperplasia of a single lobule and presents as a well-circumscribed, smooth, firm, non-tender, solitary, freely mobile mass (mouse in the breast). It is a biphasic tumor consisting of fibroblastic stroma and epithelium-lined gland. 

ANDI Classification of benign breast disorders:

Normal Disorders
Early reproductive years (15-25 yrs)
Lobular development Fibroadenoma
Stromal development Adolescent hypertrophy (Gigantomastia)
Nipple eversion Nipple inversion (subareolar abscess, Mammary duct fistula)
Later reproductive years (25-40 yrs)
Cyclical changes in menstruation Cyclical mastalgia
Involution (35-55 yrs)
Lobular involution Macrocysts, sclerosing lesions
Duct involution Dilation (duct ectasia)Sclerosis (nipple retraction)
Epithelial turnover Epithelial hyperplasia (with atypia)

 

Related Pearl: Anatomic Origins of Common Breast Lesions

questions.text: A 19-year-old girl presents with a lump in her right breast for the past 6 months. On examination, the lump is around 1 x1 cm in size, firm, and freely movable on the breast tissue. Ultrasound shows the presence of a circumscribed oval lobulated mass. Which of the following is not true regarding the given condition?

choices.text: Peak incidence is in second decade
It is a form of ANDI

questions.solution:
The clinical scenario is suggestive of fibroadenoma. Mammography may show the presence of popcorn calcification. Eggshell calcification can be seen in traumatic fat necrosis.

Fibroadenoma is a form of aberrations of normal development and involution of the breast (ANDI). The most common age group affected is 15-25 years (early reproductive period) with a peak incidence in the second decade. It arises from hyperplasia of a single lobule and presents as a well-circumscribed, smooth, firm, non-tender, solitary, freely mobile mass (mouse in the breast). It is a biphasic tumor consisting of fibroblastic stroma and epithelium-lined gland. Excision is not advised unless there is suspicious histology on FNAC.

Giant fibroadenoma is more than 5cm in size and is common in adolescent girls. It requires excision by submammary incision.

The image below shows popcorn calcification on mammography:

Based on the recent update from the 10th edition of Robins, two-thirds of fibroadenomas harbor driver mutations in MED12. The pathogenesis of the remainder is uncertain.

questions.text: A giant fibroadenoma has a diameter greater than _____
questions.solution: Giant fibroadenomas are over 5 cm in diameter and occasionally occur during puberty. They are often rapidly growing but are similar to smaller fibroadenomas and are enucleated through a submammary incision.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman presented with a lump in the left breast as shown in the image below. Biopsy done revealed increased stromal cellularity with typical leaflike architecture. Which of the following is false about this condition?

choices.text: Treatment is wide excision with margin
Originates from hormonally responsive stromal cells of the breast

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and histopathology report point to malignant cystosarcoma phyllodes, which metastasize via the bloodstream. Metastasis to lymph nodes is rare.

Phyllodes tumor also known as a sero-cystic disease of Brodie or cystosarcoma phyllodes, originates from hormonally responsive stromal cells of the breast. It is usually a benign condition and affects women >40 years of age, but can be seen in younger women. Sometimes, may develop malignant transformation.

Clinical features:

  1. Large, sometimes massive, with an unevenly bosselated surface
  2. Ulceration of overlying skin occurs because of pressure necrosis
  3. Remains mobile on the chest wall

There is no role of FNAC in phyllodes tumor. Histopathology of the lump biopsy shows increased stromal cellularity, overgrowth, and typical leaflike architecture.

Tumors are treated by excision with margins of at least 2 cm to prevent local recurrence.

Large or malignant phyllodes tumors may require a mastectomy. The axillary dissection is not recommended because axillary lymph nodes rarely get involved.

Note: Malignant phyllodes tumors contain liposarcomatous or rhabdomyosarcomatous elements rather than fibrosarcomatous elements.

questions.text: A breastfeeding mother presented to the clinic with fever and breast pain for the past 2 days. The affected breast appears as shown in the image below. There is extreme tenderness on palpation. Which of the following is the most common source for the organism causing this condition?
questions.solution:
The given scenario is suggestive of lactational mastitis. The most common source of infection is from the infant's nasopharynx.

Lactational mastitis is most commonly caused by Staphylococcus aureus present in the infant's nasopharynx. The organism enters the breast tissue through cracked nipples and multiplies in the stagnant breast milk. Patients present with fever with a firm, red, tender, and swollen quadrant of the unilateral breast.

Painful breasts must be managed by the use of analgesics. Breastfeeding should be continued if the pain is less severe. Antibiotics like flucloxacillin, co-amoxiclav are used to treat the infection. If the patient develops an abscess, then the abscess has to be drained by aspiration or incision.

  Bacterial mastitis Breast abscess
Condition Localized inflammation due to ascending infection or infection due to milk stasis  Occurs as a complication of mastitis, with pus formation
Symptoms Dull pain Throbbing pain
Signs (if any) Tenderness, erythema Point tenderness, erythema, induration of skin (if chronic) lymphadenopathy, fluctuation test +ve
Management Analgesics, antibiotics Analgesics, aspiration of pus, antibiotics

questions.text: A female patient presents with a breast abscess. An aspiration was attempted under antibiotic cover which failed to reveal any aspirate. What is the next step in management?

choices.text: Stop antibiotics as no aspirate was collected

questions.solution:
In a patient with a breast abscess, the next step after a failed aspiration is to attempt aspiration once again under antibiotic cover.

Incision and drainage is not preferred, as it can potentially interfere with breastfeeding, and delicate structures such as ducts, lobules, and tubules may be injured, possibly leading to a non-healing milk fistula.

A breast abscess is a complication of acute mastitis, which is more common in new mothers at the beginning of lactation (lactational mastitis). Non-lactational mastitis is more common in diabetic, immunosuppressed people and people predisposed by duct ectasia and periareolar infections.

Clinical features of a breast abscess include:

  • Fever and malaise
  • Localized pain and tenderness 
  • Redness and swelling of the affected breast
  • Positive fluctuation test.

An ultrasonogram of the affected breast is performed to confirm the abscess, and treatment proceeds as follows:

  • Analgesics, antipyretics, and breast support for pain and fever relief.
  • Aspiration is performed under antibiotic cover, and the pus is cultured. If aspiration proves unsuccessful, it should be reattempted after a few days.
  • Incision and drainage should be considered in cases of:
    • Mastitis unresponsive to antibiotics for 48 hours.
    • Brawny induration.
    • Progressive mastitis with persistent fever

Note:

  Bacterial mastitis Breast abscess
Condition Localized inflammation due to ascending infection or infection due to milk stasis 

Occurs as a complication of mastitis

Pus formation
Symptoms Dull pain Throbbing pain
Signs (if any)

Tenderness

Erythema

Point tenderness

Erythema

Induration of skin(if chronic)

Lymphadenopathy

Fluctuation test +ve

Pus point may be present
Management

Analgesics

Antibiotics (Dicloxacillin 500 mg every 6 hours orally; Erythromycin if allergic to penicillin)

Adequate breast support

Analgesics

Adequate breast support

Aspiration of Pus under antibiotic cover; repeated aspirations if required

Incision & drainage

questions.text: A 37- year-old woman presented to the clinic with a breast lump. Clinical examination and ultrasound revealed the presence of a single large cyst in her right breast. On aspirating the cyst, you find blood-stained fluid. What will be the next best step in the management of this patient?

choices.text: Wait for refilling and reattempt aspiration
Perform mammogram to rule out carcinoma

questions.solution:
The next step in management is the excision of the cyst.

Treatment of breast cyst:

  • If the aspirate is clear (non-blood stained) or if the cyst resolves completely then no further treatment is required.
  • If the aspirate is blood-stained or if the cyst recurs, then a core biopsy or local excision should be performed. The resulting tissue should be sent for histopathology for the exclusion of cystadenocarcinoma, especially in elderly women.

Related Pearl: Breast Lump Evaluation

questions.text: Physiological gynecomastia is not seen in which of the following?
questions.solution:
Physiological gynecomastia is not seen in obese males. In obese men, increased fat deposition over the breasts is referred to as pseudo-gynecomastia. 

Gynecomastia is defined as ≥ 2 cm subareolar breast tissue. It can be physiological or pathological.

Physiologic gynecomastia occurs during three phases of life:

  • Neonatal period
  • Adolescence
  • Senescence

Common to each of these phases is an excess of circulating estrogens in relation to circulating testosterone. Neonatal gynecomastia is caused by the action of placental estrogens on neonatal breast tissues. In adolescence, there is an excess of estradiol relative to testosterone. In senescence, the circulating testosterone level falls, resulting in relative hyperestrogenism.

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman has been experiencing breast pain for the past 6 months. The pain is present just before her menstrual period. Breast examination and mammography are normal. All of the following medications/supplements can help in reducing the pain except:
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario is suggestive of cyclical mastalgia. Caffeine is not useful in reducing pain. On the contrary, caffeine has to be avoided to reduce pain.

Medications that can be used to treat mastalgia are evening primrose oil, danazol, and tamoxifen.

questions.text: A breastfeeding mother presented to the clinic with a gradually progressive painless breast lump. On examination, a well-circumscribed and freely mobile mass was palpable. USG showed a solitary, well-defined, anechoic lesion with thin, echogenic walls. Aspiration revealed a white fluid. What is the best treatment option for this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of galactocele. The best treatment option for this condition is USG guided fine-needle aspiration. 

A galactocele is a milk-filled cavity in the breast of a woman who is usually lactating. It can be caused due to lactation problems, prolactin stimulation by drugs, or duct obstruction. 

It presents as a palpable, round, well-circumscribed, and freely mobile mass with no fever, pain, or inflammation. It is usually subareolar and unilateral.

USG guided fine-needle aspiration is both diagnostic and therapeutic. It will show thick milky white secretion confirming the diagnosis. Aspiration resolves galactocele in most cases. Surgery is done for infected cysts or recurrent cases.

Antibiotic therapy is not needed if the galactocele is not infected.

Related Pearl: Breast Lump Evaluation

questions.text: A 30-year-old female footballer presented with complaints of a lump in the breast. On examination, a hard, irregular lump was palpated. Mammography revealed calcifications as shown below. Which of the following conditions is she most likely to have?
questions.solution: In the given scenario, palpable mass and egg-shell calcifications on mammography in a young woman are suggestive of fat necrosis. It mimics breast carcinoma clinically and mammographically but has no malignant potential.
